ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the important L1 Spanish targets- reading, writing, and listening (mostly in the present tense). Not only did I learn the vocabulary for the course, but also self-discipline with the nightly homework/work targets, experience with various forms of assignments (recorded videos, presentation, etc), and confidence as a speaker.
To speak, write, and comprehend spanish
I developed more confidence in my ability to speak Spanish, and I learned a lot about hispanic culture in general.
I learned basic spanish vocabulary and grammar.
I learned how to write, read, and understand basic Spanish. I learned how to speak and hold a conversation about various topics.
This course teaches students an introduction to Spanish. Students learn basic grammar and vocabulary.
This course helped me develop basics in Spanish including vocabulary, grammar, and some cultural awareness as well.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Profesora Vazquez is caring and directly engaged with each student. There was a strong variety of in-class and homework activities that suited different learning styles- reading, recorded videos, a presentation, oral practice, etc. Even though Supersite can seem tedious, the varieties of homework do a good job of reinforcing what is learned in class and helped me prepare for the exams. The grading policy is fair and distributes weight well. The attendance policy is generous. 

Weaknesses: No major weaknesses. The only weakness that stands out was being cold-called on because it often lead to being nervous (and distracted from really learning because of that) during class, though it does keep everyone engaged.

I think this course was laid out to provide a lot of support to students learning a new language online. It also was very attentive to different aspects of learning a language beyond vocabulary and grammar. I did not think that paying $200 for a workbook was worth my money or time, however, so that is one way I would improve this course.
Strengths: needs high investment and engagement and leads to a better understanding of language. Weaknesses: sometimes has too many unnecessary assignments/homework/assessments
Very fast paced, but a lot of content covered.

Strengths: Very engaging and I was able to practice using the vocabulary and grammar I learned everyday in class. 
Weaknesses:  A lot of work that you need to keep track of.
The smaller size of classes is good as it allows for more communication during class. The pace is extremely fast and requires lots of studying to keep up.
A strength of the class was the breakout rooms to encourage participation and fluency.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the class succeeded well for being remote. The live Zoom was effective.
I think that the asynchronous and synchronous scheduled days were effective in keeping me off Zoom enough, while also engaged in the course.
Everything worked well
Zoom breakout rooms helped encourage participation and fluency.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes- if you're looking to fulfill your language requirement, Spanish is a good choice! It's practical and the cultures of Spanish-speaking countries is well incorporated for learning. The level of homework and engagement is high, but it is manageable and not too intellectually challenging.

Yes. I think my specific Spanish professor made all the difference in my decision to continue taking Spanish. I felt nurtured and heard in class, and I always wanted to try my best because I knew I would be respected.
Yes, as a level 1 course, it is a good course.
Yes. Very good basis for beginners. I am hopeful for higher level spanish.
I would recommend this course to someone who is genuinely interested in learning about the Spanish language and culture.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Additional workbook for Spanish homework, recorded videos of us talking to practice pronunciation, oral exams, listening exams, reading exams
n/a
